headline: Warnock pushes Georgia voting suppression claims, despite voters shattering turnout records
author: Jessica Chasmar
sentences: Among the Election Integrity Act's changes were to prevent government agencies from mailing applications unsolicited, require using driver's licenses or some other form of photo ID instead of signature-matching to verify their identity in absentee ballot applications, and codify ballot drop boxes into law.

"But just like his record of skyrocketing inflation, wallet busting gas prices, or surging crime in our communities, the voters of Georgia see what Warnock has done  and it's why they're going to elect a true leader and problem solver in Herschel Walker come November," Lawson continued.

And in Georgia, we know difficulty has been put in place for too many Georgians who want to vote by mail, who had to figure out a calendar of applying just early enough but not too late, who had to have what signatures so they could print things out, take a picture, upload.

Sen. Raphael Warnock, D-Ga., told congregants at Ebenezer Baptist Church that they faced "severe" voter suppression at the polls just two days before Georgia saw record voter turnout and re-elected him as the Democratic nominee.

"While Raphael Warnock continued his streak of playing politics from the pulpit and lying about Georgia's election law  a record number of voters went to the polls to cast their vote," he told Fox News Digital in a statement.

Warnock, a senior pastor at Martin Luther King Jr.'s former church in Atlanta, blasted Georgia's Republican-passed Election Integrity Act from the pulpit, saying the law is intended to diminish the "power" of Black voters.

Georgia Democratic gubernatorial nominee Stacey Abrams, another prominent critic of the Georgia election law, pushed back against claims that the primary voter turnout proved the law did not suppress Black voters.
"It's the same baseless rhetoric from Warnock that cost Georgia businesses a $100 million in lost revenue over a law that allowed for a historic voter turnout of roughly 2 million votes last week.
Warnock went on to win the Democratic primary election on May 24 in a landslide against progressive activist Tamara Johnson-Shealey, and he will face Republican nominee Herschel Walker on Nov. 8.
Secretary of State Brad Raffensperger's office announced one day before the sermon that early voting was up 168% this year compared to the 2018 primaries, and 212% up from 2020.
Stephen Lawson, president and CEO of Battleground Strategies and spokesman for 34N22, the pro- Walker Super PAC, accused Warnock of lying about the law from the pulpit.
It mandated precincts hold at least 17 days of early voting and left in place no-excuse absentee voting, while shortening the window to apply for ballots to 67 days.
